job_title: Fund Accountant Associate II in Singapore
pros: None other than the office in Capita Tower.
cons:
It's a very bad company to work with.

- they do not value capable people. They value people who are good at talking and playing politics. That said, compensation, reward and recognition is not fair. If you're good at making yourself "seen" and can be submissive, this place is for you. You will be able to progress within the company fast. You don't need to be good at work.

- state street Singapore works like a small company being affiliate of State street US. They will tell you they are MNC and is VERY big. But how big it is when policy is not clear.  The global hq have policy over flexi work, compensation, study support and that are all for show. Only a few small teams in Singapore practise that. If you're in AIS team, forget it. The "top manager" just squeeze out of all the staffs to keep the budget to herself.  If you're not their favourite, you basically can forget about anything more than basic salary. 

- smart people won't stay with the company. Because those less than that are around to make your life a hell in order to protect their interest. This in turn result in low quality of work delivered to clients and the cycle goes round. But if you're the less than capable and the boss's favourites, you'll be praised that you have done well and it's the client's problem. If you're a capable person, you'll be loaded with tasks and they will tell you that you haven't perform too well and have rooms for improvement.

job_title: Balance Sheet Substantiation Team in Bangalore
pros: There is nothing good here
cons:
1. VP/AVP hire their relatives or friends and remain close to them and promote them with good rating irrespective of their quality of work. Those people have easy access to AVP/VP any time. Other people are ignored and do not have easy access.
2. Seniors are good in flattering to get promotion even though they have no quality to become team lead.
3. There is no meaning of the team for seniors. They are focused on their own growth and career and no time to hear team members and address their queries.
4. No process at all for anything. Every month process/timeline changes as new thought comes in senior's mind. They want you to finish whole month's work in one day suddenly as their thoughts are changing continuously.
5. Seniors are themselves confused and have no clear idea to do any activity and they set-up call with whole team for time pass and confuse whole team.
6. Do not go by name of this team. Your whole work will be around reconciliations only where you will be only preparing/reviewing reconciliations (data entry), nothing else. There is no single accounting activity at all here, so no learning in any form.
7. You will forget everything you have learnt in the past and regret your decision to join this team or company where you will just be doing data entry job for which no specific knowledge is required.
8. No room to ask any question about anything, if you ask you will not be included in anything or excluded by VP/MD.
9. No work life balance at all. Even for such useless work AVP/VP want you to login on weekends to just show off their seniors because they do not have any plan for weekdays.
10. No team meetings at all at any level as they are working as individual contributor.
11. Seniors will force you to like random linkedin comment posted by their senior and keep track of it.
12. Your rating is already predecided by VP/AVP irrespective of your work. Their friend/relative get good rating & promotion and easy access to them and you get downgrade rating and it does not matter whatever you have done.
13. No one asks your feedback about your seniors or culture. Even survey from HR is just formality where you do not see any impact of it.
14. Work culture is toxic where no one listens, blame others for their mistakes, ignores ethical practices etc.
15. If you want to waste few years of your career without learning and frustrating then can join this team.
16. Not a single reason to join this team. But other teams in this company have similar type of culture. It is honey trap

pros: The people you work with are generally great.  Some of them have years and years of critical experience which make them worth their weight in gold.
cons:
State Street's whole emphasis (from a finance perspective) is on cutting costs, i.e. in human capital, to improve its profitability.  The focus is on shifting work to low cost destinations (particularly India), without replacing key personnel as they leave in the U.S. and other western locations.  This is understandable, except for the fact that they apply a shotgun approach, shelving whole departments without thought or due diligence - checking to see the level of experience and knowledge of the personnel they are letting go.  Consequently, huge chasms in abilities are created - seriously impacting the company's level of service to its customers.

The culture at the company has changed dramatically for the worse over the last few years, particularly under the leadership of the current CFO.  To him, people are purely cogs in a wheel, and are seen simply as costs.  Very different to one of his predecessors, who actually valued the human element in the company's functions.

Time will tell if this methodology will work for the company long-term, but I suspect that issues will grow as current employees struggle to cope with massively increasing work-loads, with minimal support or head count backup being made available.

Despite the extra workloads you're expected to bear, the company pays less than its peers, unless you are a recent employee, in which case they have to pay you at market rates.

job_title: Front Office Support Officer in London, England
pros:
The biggest advantage of working here is the people are approachable in many areas of the bank. There is no issue with speaking to people more senior to get something resolved to meet your target.
Some teams are focused on hybrid working dependent upon role
Work is less stressful than other big names as only FX and Securities Finance offerings
cons:
The compensation is below par compared to competitors - there are big cuts and migration of roles together to pay below salary for doing 2 jobs. Also when someone leaves a role, they advertise the role one to two ranks down to cut costs. This has happened several times with good colleagues leaving.
There is a strong emphasis that Boston run the show and other regions do not have their own presence. 
There are several unprofessional situations within teams including a VP asking a contractor about a colleagues nationality out of context, and passive-aggressive behaviour with some staff. Last, the IT systems always break and is not fit for purpose to carry out your work.
There is a bureaucratic and outdated look to banking that State Street needs to adapt to change and take risk to be able to compete with the big boys

pros: Don't remember any of Pros
cons:
- Old technology stack
- Small overlaping with US zone (be ready to work extra hours or start later if you are in Europe)
- VPN/Netword issues on State Street side (if you want to download some installers you need to ask someone to pack them first and put them to share folder otherwise you can wait for 2-3 hr when download will be completed)
- Very old and complex product
- No sonar checks so everyone can commit everything to break application build
- Be ready to test not only your changes but changes of your teammate even if you are software engineer (we have only 1 QA that was shared between teams)
- Once you did some change in application code you need to run unit-tests to be sure that everything is working as expected. Thats totally fine but full unit-test run can take 40-60 minutes.
- No work-life balance

Once I left this company I got an email from payroll team that I need to pay some money back due to their mistake. No excuse from their side.
I can't recommend this company.

review_title: A home, but oversized and always messy
pros:
Good, friendly atmosphere within IT
Supportive management from outside of Poland
Multiple lateral move options
Can reliably plan your future working here as opportunities are always present
Flexible working arrangements, no pressure within IT to RTO, we come to the office when we like.
Often flat structures within teams, good collaboration.
cons:
Pay is relatively low and even when you're promoted the payrise does not reflect it, then you're sitting on low end of the pay for the grade for years.
Since at least 2009 there are neverending talks about how environment remains challenging and need to cut costs for the benefit of shareholders.
Executive level management seems enthusiastic and engaged, but their declarations often are contradictory to what the senior management are actually doing.
Organization is huge and responsibility is diluted. Someone commited to solve your problem and not push it onto someone else is hard to find. It's also hard to push any changes, and extremely hard to innovate. There are some incompetent people especially on the business side who became managers due to their tenure only and thanks to the fact they work in low cost location. On the other hand there are plenty of competent workers in the US who never get promoted or even get laid off and never replaced. 
Also there is preference to hire for a high position   an incompetent but good at selling themselves external candidate rather than promote internally someone who would be an ideal fit.

pros: blank blank blank blank blank
cons:
Throughout Mod 1 I have gained valuable knowledge and experiences. As I reflect, I have utilized the feedback that I received in the early weeks of the MOD. At that time, the group was consistent in their recognition of my organization skills and willingness to jump in to provide support. Overall, I had received 4's from my group members in all categories except for "positive personal style" for which I received a split score of 3 and 4. These were areas that I focused on improving throughout the continuation of the MOD and the group work that I participated in. I feel that I was successful in this, as my group provided feedback such as “As the facilitator she was a good project leader always keeping us aligned with objectives and making sure that everything was submitted on time” and “Danielle was an important member of the team and kept us focused on the goal at hand. She was a hardworking member of our team and always came prepared.”
From a project management perspective, one of the biggest lessons that I have learned is to plan further out. While we remained vigilantly aware of the deadlines, we could have planned more effectively in terms of managing our workload leading up to the project deliverables.
I look forward to taking the lessons I have learned throughout the past few months into MOD 2. As I become a member of a new group, I hope to take these experiences forth to continue to improve and bring value to my new group.

review_title: Pay Discriminates against women. Pays less than any other banks
pros: It is a job.I have no other pros.
cons: I have worked very hard for this company for 7 + years. It has recently come to my attention they have been paying me 30,000 less than male counterparts of the same rank as me, regardless how I have actually put in more hours, and have more accomplishments and done more for the company than they have. State street will take advantage of you, especially if you are a woman or a minority. Lay offs occur often, and employees are expected to take on more people’s work often and the work load is forever increasing however pay doesn’t even keep up with inflation. It is hyper competitive and bosses often will remind you how you could be laid off at the drop of a hat. My managers often use humiliation to get people to do what they want. Do not apply here, it will tear down your soul.

pros: Established, stable financial company — one of the biggest and most respected in the world — with leadership that pushes to get the most out of every employee, every hour, every day and every dollar. If you are ambitious, tolerant of change and relentlessly optimistic, you’ll do well here. Leadership is not afraid of change or tackling big, important challenges. Exciting work if you’re in a visionary part of the company.
cons: Soul-crushing if you let it get to you. Burdened by layers of bureaucracy, ‘process management’ and cost cutting. Constant change — including clockwork reorgs and layoffs — leave many feeling unsettled and hopeless.  Employees bear the brunt of sub-par technology, laughably low budgets and endless scrutiny that multiplies the time it takes to do anything. Very little ethnic diversity at the EVP and C-levels. Hollow talk about values and work life balance is undercut by brutal ‘steamroller’ executives who do not seem to value or consider the voice of their teams, making absurd requests that have no bearing on the realities of what’s possible. On top of that, flat salary and ‘merit-based’ compensation for years on end wears thin. Many end up ‘donating’ countess hours every year.

review_title: I discourage fresh colleges grads taking a client ops/service role in SSGS
job_title: Client Service Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Learned through trial by fire. SSB put me in a group where they started to offshore a lot of roles into India. There were definitely plenty of opportunities to learn and figure things at the ground. Their technology was surprisingly better than most firms I went through. Their healthcare package, education reimbursement and 401Ks were pretty good. ERG groups were pretty big and super active.
cons:
Terrible entry pay. Don't do it as your first job out of college on the SSGS. You are better off working on the SSGM side or SSGA. The starting salary point would be lower and your promotions will be pegged to that base pay. SSGM / SSGA could easily pay you $20-$30K extra as an entry level. Most folks in SSGS are unmotivated and stay there for life. 

My team went from an 8 people group down to 2 people to handle over 1K emails a day. Management couldn't seem to understand why we were making so many mistakes at that point. I had to be online until the files go out, which could be as late as midnight. On top of that my client complained about my WFH once so management took away my WFH privilege (this was happened in 2018/2019). I wouldn't want to work here if my employer couldn't even protect my own interests. I left soon after that happened.

There's a lot of finger pointing blaming culture here during my time there and teams are put into silos. Everyone follows their Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) and won't think flexibly to make the process better.

There's plenty of diversity at entry level. However I could tell there weren't a lot of minority representations once you hit the VPs/MDs/EVP levels and above.
